text: I worked at an all-remote agency for 7 years and I know it's different now with the pandemic, but our twice-annual in-person retreats were a real game changer. Spending a couple of days with someone helps everyone have more of a human connection over screens for the rest of the year.

elements.text: I worked at an all-remote agency for 7 years and I know it's different now with the pandemic, but our twice-annual in-person retreats were a real game changer. Spending a couple of days with someone helps everyone have more of a human connection over screens for the rest of the year.

text:
Agency folks: Talk to me about how you qualify leads! We (small edit agency focusing on fin svcs, tech, healthcare, business) have really built our networks over the last few years and are getting 2-4 inbound inquiries a week. (We even got a new client after our managing partner posted on LinkedIn looking for writers. :thinking_face:)

We have always taken a very personal approach to biz dev -- meeting individually w/ prospective clients, sending customized clips packages, etc. We have been at max capacity for about 6 months, and that approach is no longer efficient. I've started screening out the prospects who are basically looking for a glorified content farm, and put together some canned responses we can have ready to go. But that only covers about 30% of the leads we get. I imagine there are 20% more that definitely merit the same process we have been following. So I'm curious how y'all deal efficiently with the murky middle ones, that could be fantastic or just tire-kickers.

text:
Hi Michaela! I won't claim to be an expert on this in the agency world, but I've seen it a lot in my 'day job' at SaaS companies.

I just checked out your website and have a couple suggestions:

• You might be able to do more screening with your contact form (assuming this is where your inbound leads are coming from). Your form fields are pretty generic, and adding some more granularity might help with filtering (eg "Budget", "Type of Work", etc)
• Clarify your positioning on your site so everyone knows who you'll work with (and who you won't). <@UUXMCJQ15> shared a great Loom video i<https://content-career-growth.slack.com/archives/CJ7QJ4WKB/p1643767932117929|n this thread> that shows how he does this on his site.

Clarify your positioning on your site so everyone knows who you'll work with (and who you won't).

that shows how he does this on his site.

text:
Agree with Lawrence here. Definitely add budget and use some sort of automation to qualify them and send them a response email if they're DQ’ed, letting them know why and some recommended resources in their range.

We used to get way too many inquiries that weren't qualified either. So I put pricing up and that helped a ton. Way fewer leads, but way less wasted time (for both the lead and us).
